text: Playing around with <@U01DJ59B2SE>’s immersed boundary implementation :triangular_ruler:
Here you are plotting temp, I assume. But the ibm branch version doesn’t have tracers enforced, yet. Are you just using the velocity enforcement to control subsequent temperature domain? <@UEP056STX>

text: Didn't realize there should be separate enforcement for tracers.

text: So I guess it's relying on velocity enforcement to get the temperature field right.

text: I only ran it for 1 hour so maybe it gets worse with time? I assume it only gets more accurate if tracers are properly enforced.

text: yeah if you have boundary conditions you’d want to enforce for your tracer, you’d need to have that in there. The velocity profile probably keeps it in check. If you include the “immersed” side in the plot does it show temperature “leakage?”  I need to add the loop that would allow for an IBM enforcement of those. I was working on it a while ago, but it was giving me an error. So, I didn’t add it to the branch, and I never got back to working on that aspect :grimacing:

text: Ah I see, yeah non-default boundary conditions wouldn't work like this. I was going for no-slip velocity BCs and no-flux tracer BCs so maybe I got something pretty close to this?

elements.text: Ah I see, yeah non-default boundary conditions wouldn't work like this. I was going for no-slip velocity BCs and no-flux tracer BCs so maybe I got something pretty close to this?

text: Are you suggesting plotting something like volume-integrated temperature for the grid points inside and outside the immersed boundary to look at temperature leakage?

elements.text: Are you suggesting plotting something like volume-integrated temperature for the grid points inside and outside the immersed boundary to look at temperature leakage?

text: And no worries! I'm just playing around with the immersed boundary implementation since John and I had some ideas for extending previous work by adding in sloped walls and we wanted to see how the plume looks like with an immersed boundary vs. tilted gravity.
